body: Here are some of the best inexpensive places reviewed in the Dining section this year. ABRAçO ESPRESSO86 East Seventh Street, East Village; (212) 388-9731. title: Resolution: Dine Well Without Breaking the Budget

body: IN 1963, while my dad was on leave from the Air Force, my parents took a trip to Copenhagen. The Danish krone was worth about 14 cents, so my mother bought a black leather Swan chair with a footstool and two orange Egg chairs, designed by Arne Jacobsen. title: CITY ROOM

body: Theater Steven McElroy Playwrights have tackled the messy subject of war at least since the Greek tragedians did, and if their dramatic pleas for peace have gone largely unheeded, the dramatist's compulsion to write about the topic has hardly waned. title: THE WEEK AHEAD | OCT. 5 -- OCT. 11 | Theater

body: IT'S not easy being a modernist in a town known for traditional architecture. For Stan Allen, an architect, and his wife, Polly Apfelbaum, an artist, finding a contemporary house in history-laden Princeton, N.J., was a process fraught with disappointment. Three times, Ms. Apfelbaum said, they found houses they liked, only to be outbid by developers
title: HABITATS; Thoroughly Modern, Amid the Traditional

body: WITH its sedate, leafy streets, fine old homes and churches, lush gardens and lofty harbor views, Brooklyn Heights feels like a staid patrician neighborhood where time has stood still since the 1800s. But more has gone on there than its quiet streets and house-proud gentry let on. ''The myth of the white-gloved ladies is that this was always a
title: WEEKEND EXPLORER; Brooklyn's Home To the Gentry And the Not-So

body: PUT it under enough pressure, and the Box will talk. Three weeks ago a pair of former burlesque performers at the Box, a downtown theater/cabaret/hot spot, posted photographs on their page at MySpace.com of what they said was its filthy dressing room. The women added a litany of explicit charges about the personal habits and business practices of
title: Imperiled, the Box Defends Itself

body: AROUND TOWN TAKEOVER IN BROOKLYN The BAMcinématek is known for series on auteurs or masterpieces that its curators want you to know about. For ''Up All Night in 1985,''
title: Spare Times

body: When the third season of ''Ugly Betty'' begins on Thursday, viewers who see the show's star, America Ferrera, stumble past the Brooklyn Bridge or the Empire State Building will be seeing something new: New York. Until this season, the ABC show was produced in Los Angeles, where its exterior shots were frequently filmed in front of green screens,
title: Thanks to Tax Credits, the New York You See on TV Is More Likely the Real City

body: What is it about Snow White? In both popular culture and in more rarefied forms of performance, she has had her share of knocks -- like Rob Lowe's infamous duet with the squeaky-voiced character at the 1989 Academy Awards show and Ann Liv Young's bawdy interpretation showcased at the Kitchen in 2007. Now the French artist Catherine Ba presents her
title: DANCE REVIEW | 'THE SNOW WHITE PROJECT'; No One Is Sleepy or Dopey, and They Sure Don't Seem Happy

body: OUTFITTING a nursery used to be a snap: pink for girls, blue for boys, yellow for babies whose parents were a bit more progressive. Put a crib here and a bassinet there, mount an animal mobile that plays ''Farmer in the Dell,'' and the work was done. Today, there is a wider variety of well-designed products that are sophisticated and eco-friendly.
title: SHOPPING WITH : Christiane Lemieux | Growing Room

body: Hatch, N.M., is to a certain kind of chili as Vidalia, Ga., is to a sweet onion: a place of distinctive terroir that has lent its name to the ingredient. Vidalia onions are easily found in supermarkets, but Hatch green chilies, which are eagerly awaited by devotees of Southwestern and Mexican cooking in late summer and early fall, are not. Kitchen
title: FOOD STUFF; A Green Chili Worth Waiting for, And Seeking Out

body: In December two professional dancers, Brandi Norton and Sonja Kostich, were sitting at the bar at the Mercer Hotel in SoHo tossing back cocktails. After hours of conversation mostly about the dearth of jobs, they got serious, switched to wine and did what countless slightly crazy souls have done before them: they decided to start their own company.
title: First Steps and Leaps Of D.I.Y. Dance Company

body: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: KAY FRANCIS She was the most popular actress at Warner Brothers before Bette Davis came along. title: WHAT'S ON TODAY

author: Compiled by Kris Ensminger E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: BoCoCa, a term coined several years ago for a shopping guide, refers to the junction of Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens. While it hasn't exactly caught on with the fervor of, say, TriBeCa or Dumbo, it does identify the site of a vibrant dining scene. These places have all opened in the past year or so. Black Mountain Wine House (718)
title: GOOD EATING | BOCOCA; Brooklyn Cornucopia

body: NOT until they began visiting open houses did Nicolle and Jeff Pillartz realize they had entirely different visions for their new home. The couple planned to buy a Brooklyn two-bedroom within a quick commute of Manhattan. But after they saw a co-op at 35 Clark Street in Brooklyn Heights, they realized how dissimilar their tastes were. She found the
title: THE HUNT; Competing Visions

title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN SUMMER ON THE HUDSON For those of us who've paid little attention to the redevelopment of the Far West Side, Riverside Park South, the well-tended space beneath the West Side Highway near 70th Street, is often overshadowed by its far more developed counterparts. Conceived as a peace offering of sorts by the real-estate titans who
title: Spare Times

body: THREE distinct and distinctly walkable neighborhoods line the Brooklyn waterfront under the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. But though they share the East River and the York Street stop on the F train, they couldn't be more different -- Fulton Ferry is a tourist standard, Dumbo is an industrial area gentrified into low-key hipness, and Vinegar Hill
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | THE EAST RIVER; In Brooklyn, Sharing a River But Not Much Else

body: Opening a rock club in New York is not as easy as it used to be. There's the insane cost of real estate, as well as fierce competition as the battered music industry looks to live performances for steady income, and national promoters expand their reach into smaller spaces. But hardest of all, said Peter Shapiro, who owned Wetlands in TriBeCa from
title: New Club Twins Rock 'N' Bowl

title: ON THE MARKET

body: Even as the Brooklyn Flea was being called a watershed addition to the continuing refurbishment of the borough's brownstone neighborhoods, the market's founder, Jonathan Butler, had an inkling that perhaps it did not square with everybody's idea of what Sunday in Brooklyn should be. title: Flea Market Is a Success, And Neighbors Are Furious

body: A VETERINARY technician named Andrea Annette was riding the No. 3 train two months ago when a stranger in sunglasses caught her eye. The two exchanged smiles, and Ms. Annette later discovered that he had written to her in Missed Connections, a section of the Craigslist Web site where people regretting their shyness make public appeals to The One
title: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; In Pursuit of the One Who Got Away

body: Erik Baard was 200 yards away from a smooth, placid day on the water. The weather was warm, the water picturesque, and Mr. Baard and 26 other kayakers were just about to finish their trip Friday on the Brooklyn waterfront, from Red Hook to Governors Island and finally on to Dumbo. But then Mr. Baard heard a commotion and looked back, and suddenly,
title: Kayakers Rescued Near Waterfall in Harbor

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites 'GOING PLACES (DOING STUFF)' Necessity breeds invention. Also, gas is expensive, and everyone loves a road trip. title: Spare Times

body: TOO bad sainthood is not generally conferred on bakers, for there is one who is a possible candidate for canonization. She fulfills most of the requirements: (1) She's dead. (2) She demonstrated heroic virtue. (3) Cults have been formed around her work. (4) Her invention is considered by many to be a miracle. The woman: Ruth Graves Wakefield. Her
title: Perfection? Hint: It's Warm and Has a Secret

body: THREE stories above the Peas and Pickles market in Dumbo, Brooklyn, behind a blank door in a nondescript converted industrial building, two sculptors stood back and watched last week as a former vice presidential chief of staff climbed up onto a wooden box and peered across their studio. title: DISPATCHES; Abe, We Hardly Knew Ye This Way

body: ''Three. Two. One. Fire!'' With a satisfying boom, flames exploded into the air on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. Standing a few feet away, Grzegorz Jarzyna, a Polish theater director sporting a slick leather jacket and a soul patch, looked on approvingly. Mr. Jarzyna was at Jauchem & Meeh, a special-effects shop, with his staff
title: Scottish Play Gets Polish Makeover

body: ON a morning early this spring, Lee Brian Schrager phoned Kimberly Yorio, a publicist who works with chefs. Ms. Yorio had been trying to figure out how to promote a client's book, and she used the occasion of the call to ask about the New York City Wine & Food Festival that Mr. Schrager was planning for October. ''Would you consider doing something
title: Catering To Star Chefs

body: GOING to our local playground in Brooklyn can be painful. When friends are there, it's great. But it's hard to make small talk with people I barely know about high-tech strollers, whose kid is taking French lessons (mine are not), the pros and cons of gifted-and-talented programs -- the usual nightmare urban-mommy conversation. So, come late
title: SUMMER IN THE CITY; New York's Big Backyard

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites PREVIOUSLY ON LOST Fan-fiction writers have nothing on Adam Schatz and Jeff Curtin, Brooklynites and the founders of what they believe is the world's first (only?) TV-recap rock band. Technically a duo, Previously on Lost was born about a year ago, when Mr. Schatz, 20, a jazz saxophone studies major at New York
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., a Community Day and Quilt Show, with quilting demonstrations and antique items on display. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Tours on weekdays at 2:30 p.m. and on weekends at 2 and 3:30
title: Spare Times

body: In 2005, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority considered, then backed away from, a proposal to ban photography on subways and buses (unless a permit was obtained). In 2007, the Bloomberg administration faced a firestorm from photographers and filmmakers over a plan to restrict video recording on streets and in other public spaces. Stephen C.
title: CITY ROOM; Library Looks at Photography and the City

body: RICHARD SAJA is always on the lookout for toile, but not to buy a few yards for a dressing room armchair. He looks at the fabric as the basis for his art. Mr. Saja, a 43-year-old textile designer, has been interfering with toile for years, embroidering fur on humans, wings on monkeys and bugs on flowers (like ladybugs, flies and cockroaches, though
title: Fabrics and Fabrications

body: Before sunrise on Tuesday morning, a strange sight began to appear on Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn: a six-foot-tall metal drill bit seemed to emerge from the wooden pier, covered in genuine East River mud and revolving slowly beneath the glow of the Manhattan skyline. On Wednesday it will grow into a 12-foot-tall industrial-looking behemoth
title: Telescope Takes a Long View, to London

body: NEW YORK PHOTO FESTIVAL Various sites in Dumbo, Brooklyn Through Sunday Anyone with even a slight interest in contemporary photography should go to Dumbo for the New York Photo Festival this weekend. Organized by powerHouse Books and VII Photo Agency, the event is not to be confused with the more familiar type of art or photography fair in which
title: Art in Review

body: To the Editor: ''In City's Growing Neighborhoods, Public Schools Face Pupil Jam'' (front page, May 9) describes the latest twist in New York City's school facilities crisis. In 1988 the New York State Legislature, before creating the School Construction Authority, found that ''many of the schools are overcrowded, unsafe, unhealthy and unusable.''
title: LETTERS; The Woes of New York's Public Schools

body: Of all the draws of 200 Chambers Street, a luxury TriBeCa condo with floor-to-ceiling windows and a swimming pool, Sherry Hsiung was particularly attracted by Public School 234, the celebrated elementary school next door. But when Dr. Hsiung, a dermatologist, tried to register her son for kindergarten last month, she was shocked to hear that
title: In City's Growing Neighborhoods, Public Schools Face Pupil Jam

body: IN the opening moments of Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest chapter of the cinematically styled video game franchise, two men are standing at the side of a boat, watching a familiar sight drift into view. Through their eyes, we see a digitized, 21st-century retelling of a scene that greeted numerous generations of new arrivals to an unknown country:
title: A Strange City Called Home

body: ZEB STEWART wasn't interested in finding a new home. He was happy where he was, on the parlor floor of a two-family row house in Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn, with two fireplaces and a backyard. It was ''like a little French country home,'' he said, renting for $1,800 a month. Mr. Stewart, 36, who does sculpture, metalwork and furniture design, was
title: THE HUNT; New King of 'Bushwick Castle'

body: The craziest thing about Enda Walsh's ''Walworth Farce,'' the galloping gothic comedy out of Ireland that opened on Friday night at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn, is how quickly it starts making sense. For the first few minutes of this ripping, warping family portrait, a production of the Druid Theater Company of Galway, you're apt to feel that
title: THEATER REVIEW; Another Day, Another Play, for Rotten Old Dad

body: MANHATTANITES tend to regard a trip to Brooklyn with the same shudder and loathing that Brooklynites reserve for trips to Hoboken. It's psychological; it feels more difficult than it really is. While well-known to real estate agents, the waterfront neighborhood of Dumbo (an acronym for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass) is still new enough
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER | ZOë; Little Hedge Fund on the Prairie

author: Jeff Byles, an editor at The Architect's Newspaper, is the author of ''Rubble: Unearthing the History of Demolition.''
body: NEW YORK'S streets are as gritty as the city's reputation, traffic-clogged canyons of concrete where New Yorkers, on foot and in vehicles, jostle and growl, exulting all the while. Stared down a Hummer lately? Yet there is a growing desire to tame New York's 5,800 miles of streets, sidewalks and highways, which constitute the city's principal
title: Taking Back the Streets

body: Dr. Jennifer Berson and Adam James Halper are to be married on Sunday evening at Bubby's Pie Company, a restaurant in Dumbo, Brooklyn. Rabbi David Rosenn is to officiate. The bride, 30, who will take her husband's name, is a second-year resident in psychiatry at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital in Manhattan. She graduated magna cum laude
title: Jennifer Berson, Adam Halper

body: TO judge by his scabrous, anguished dramas, filled with bullying adults and angst-ridden children, you might think that Enda Walsh had the most miserable childhood in the history of Irish playwrights. But he says it isn't true. In a gee-whiz tone, Mr. Walsh, 41, describes a happy home life with loving and supportive parents. ''My father was quite a
title: Mr. Normal's Dysfunctional Irish Families

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. BEACH HOUSE (Wednesday) This male-female Baltimore duo plays gorgeously languid songs highlighted by eerie organ lines and the amorous alto of Victoria Legrand. With Papercuts and Luke Temple. At 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111,
title: Pop

body: GRACE LUMINATO never expected to live in a condominium in a modern high-rise in Brooklyn, a borough she had ignored during most of her life in Manhattan. In 1990, Ms. Luminato left her native Melbourne, Australia, and set off to see the world. She arrived in Manhattan six months later, after exploring Asia and Europe, and promptly made it her home.
title: HABITATS | VINEGAR HILL, BROOKLYN; She Left Her Heart in Manhattan

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. ACID MOTHERS TEMPLE, DANAVA (Tuesday) The prolific Japanese band Acid Mothers Temple describes its style as ''extreme trip music,'' which basically means big, sloppy noise jams. It doesn't necessarily mean peasant frocks and long wizard's robes, but those are usually part of the act too. With
title: Pop

body: OUT-OF-TOWN visitors are excused if they get overwhelmed walking down a busy New York City street. There's so much going on that no one can possibly take it all in. Natives long ago learned to filter the sensory onslaught: some exclusively people watch (looking for fashion trends, seeking potential mates); or building watch (admiring architecture,
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | STREET ART; To the Trained Eye, Museum Pieces Lurk Everywhere

body: George Dombek pays rent on his 1,400-square-foot, light-filled studio at 20 Jay Street with his paintings, which lately focus on water towers and upside-down tin pails on posts. The Galapagos Art Space will pay $6.82 per square foot a year when it moves into a 102-year-old, 10,000-square-foot former stable at 16 Main Street this spring. St. Ann's
title: The Lords of Dumbo Make Room for the Arts, at Least for the Moment

body: JAZZ Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. SFJAZZ COLLECTIVE Transition has come again to the SFJAZZ Collective, an eight-piece band established in 2004 by the Bay Area arts organization SFJAZZ. For its first few years, the ensemble, which combines jazz repertory with original music by its members, had a clear public
title: Jazz

body: With the help of students from P.S. 307, Tattfoo Tan, a Malaysian-born artist, has installed a mural on Front Street in Brooklyn, left, based on his ''Nature Matching System'' place mat, far left. The place mat was inspired by a visit to the Union Square Greenmarket. Mr. Tan photographed his purchases and, using Photoshop, created a grid of squares
title: PUBLIC ART; Paint-by-Vegetable Mural (With a Reminder to Eat Them)

body: A selected list of upcoming shows. Dates are subject to change. FEBRUARY ADDING MACHINE The story of poor Mr. Zero resonates in this time of relentless technological change. Mr. Zero is an office drudge, you see, who after 25 years of devoted service is replaced by a machine. Of course he murders his boss. Sound familiar? The story is from Elmer
title: SPRING THEATER SPECIAL; Beebo Brinker, Meet Mr. Zero

body: The tale of the warehouse-turned-loft building by the banks of the East River in Brooklyn seemed a familiar one, at first. Artists move into a decrepit building, quietly rehabilitate it, live and work there. The city eventually catches on and issues a flurry of violations, forcing the artists into the streets. Developers circle, landlords yield and
title: After Evacuation, Artists Begin an Effort to Save Their Haven

author: E-mail: cityletters@nytimes.com
body: To the Editor: Like Nathaniel Rich (''His City, Lost and Found,'' Feb. 3), I am a city kid displaced in my own city. When I am asked the obligatory ''So, where are you from?'' I answer: ''I'm from here. I grew up in the Village.'' The reply is always: ''Really? I never meet anyone from here.'' Since we are middle-class and well educated, you can't
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Remembering a City They Hoped Would Be Theirs

body: Ice cream après ski? When it's a snowy scoop of WhiteFace Mint Chip, tasting of peppermint and studded with chocolate slivers, why not? This flavor, named for one of New York's highest mountains, is among eight made by Adirondack Creamery, and was first sold in that region. The ice cream, now made in Kingston, N.Y., near the Catskills, is made
title: FOOD STUFF; Down From the Mountains, New York Ice Cream

body: DURING her apartment hunt, Catherine Brophy carried with her the essential tool of her trade -- a loupan, the traditional feng shui compass. That way, she could easily check the direction of an apartment's door, even though she could generally sense whether the orientation made for good feng shui. Still, she liked to be sure. The city includes
title: THE HUNT; Home Is Where Harmony Is

body: ''When I arrived in New York in 1935,'' the photographer Rudy Burckhardt recalled near the end of his life, ''I was amazed at the difference in scale between the people and the buildings.'' Over the course of his career he figured out a way to make the city's architecture fit the human scale he favored. Faced with the same choice, Burckhardt's wife
title: ART REVIEW | 'PICTURING NEW YORK'; Views of the City, His and Hers, With Lens and Brush

body: Young Soon Kim, the founder and director of the White Wave modern dance company, has a thing for festivals. But there are usually several choreographers and performers who stand out in what are essentially showcase series. The Cool New York festival's program on Friday, at the company's John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, opened on a high note with
title: DANCE REVIEW; Moon and Earth and Sky: A Festival's Long Reach

body: ELEANOR ALPER embarked upon a hunt for a new home because her husband was dying. The couple lived at 2 Fifth Avenue in a one-bedroom on a high floor with a big terrace. ''It was such a great place,'' she said, with a full-arch view of Washington Square Park. Some neighboring units overlooked just half the arch. ''I never thought I would move,'' she
title: THE HUNT; Starting a New Life in Brooklyn
